Lesson Content:
Your baby is old enough now to really enjoy having a comforter +/- a dummy. If you haven’t done so already, introduce a comforter that will provide your baby with something to become attached to and see as a positive sleep cue.

Pop the comforter down your top every so often so it takes on your smell, and leave it in your baby’s cot.

If your baby takes a dummy, then choosing a comforter that you can attach multiple dummies to is important. Once past 6 months, I don’t recommend ditching the dummy until closer to 2.5-3 years old as it becomes too hard and not worth the battle.

Lesson Name: Finding and Replacing their Own Dummy
Lesson Content:
You can begin to teach your baby to find and replace their own dummy from 6 months old. Now that your baby is between 8-12 months old, they are very capable of learning to do this independently.

Finding and replacing their own dummy begins with showing them how to pick it up themselves and pop it in their own mouth the right way. Make it into a game during the day and let them have lots of practice.

Step 1: During awake time, place your baby's hand onto their dummy.
Step 2: Help them pick it up with their hand.
Step 3: Guide it to their mouth with them.

The sooner they are able to find and replace their own dummy, the quicker they will be able to self-soothe when they wake from a nap or overnight, and at 8-12 months old they are definitely able to do this themselves.

Your baby should now be progressing well with solids, and if you have any concerns, please speak to your GP or pediatrician. By now, your baby should be on 3 meals per day and sometimes a snack as well.

  • Always offer meals at least 1 hour before nap or bedtime as we don’t want your baby going to bed uncomfortable on a full tummy.
  • Ensure you’re offering cooled, boiled water at meal times in a sippy cup or straw cup.
  • As your baby approaches 9 months of age, they may show interest in dropping the post-lunchtime milk feed. If this is the case, then it should be replaced with some afternoon tea.
  • This stage becomes more about the food than the breast milk/formula. It is important to make sure that babies are progressing with more complex textures of foods and being given many opportunities to try a range of textures. The consistency should be more mashed and chunky now, as well as some baby-led feeding encouraged.

Your baby should now be having protein at lunchtime and dinner, which will help stabilize their blood sugars overnight and help reduce night wake-ups.25-50g of a protein source should be added. These include foods like chicken, turkey, red meats, fish, egg, and dairy. Beans, legumes, and tofu are a great source of protein and can now be introduced. 

Protein can also be offered at dinnertime now; however, if your baby starts waking frequently overnight, then take a step back from the protein at dinnertime for a couple of weeks, then reintroduce it.

GENERAL NOTE:
I'm deliberate in the 25-50g of protein measurement—I don't want parents googling micronutrients of protein sources—it's a general guide to make protein-rich meals.

Lesson Name: Including Your Baby at Family Meal Times
Lesson Content:
Offering your baby what the rest of the family is eating is absolutely essential as your baby gets older. I discourage people from looking at ‘baby cookbooks’ as a version of a family meal is always best (before any salt or chili is added to it). I suggest that by 12 months of age, your baby will be eating family meals, and the only way to introduce them to those foods is to let them try them (again, slightly modified so as not to have salt or chili).

Tip: If you aren’t eating your main meal when your baby does at 5 PM, then it can be helpful to make a bit extra for your baby for the next night and heat it up for them. This will ensure they are still getting variety and eating what you are, plus it means you don’t have to cook anything special just for them.

A food/milk imbalance can occur when your baby has large milk feeds or excessive milk feeds and is then no longer hungry enough to take solids. Our suggested routines take this into account and will give you a guide as to what is the best time and order to offer milk feeds and solids. At this age breastmilk/formula is still your baby’s primary source of nutrition however we also want them to be hungry enough to take an interest in solids and have a wide variety of flavours and textures.

Reverse cycling occurs when a baby is having a large amount of calories overnight, which then impacts their hunger and calories consumed during the day. At this age, we want your baby to be consuming most of their calories during the day from both solids and breastmilk or formula feeds.

Reducing the amount of feeds overnight they're having can significantly increase their daytime calories and is another thing that will help them sleep more soundly both day and night. A key indicator that your baby is having too many calories overnight is if they wake at 6:30-7 AM and aren't interested in their milk feed or breakfast.

See our Dropping Night Feeds video in Chapter 1.2 - Routine on how to reduce and eliminate your baby's overnight feeds.

Foods high in tryptophan content can help promote sleep as they release neurotransmitters serotonin and melatonin, which are our sleep hormones.

Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves several important purposes, like nitrogen balance in adults and growth in infants. It also creates niacin, which is essential in creating the neurotransmitter serotonin. This is converted to melatonin in the presence of darkness. Melatonin is our sleep hormone, so a healthy production of this is important.

Foods high in tryptophan include turkey, chicken, bananas, oats, kidney beans, dairy, and eggs.

Note - these don’t have to specifically be eaten at night to promote sleep, they can be enjoyed all throughout the day.

Packet/pouch food is amazingly convenient - it’s affordable, sterile, mobile. It’s absolutely OK to use packet food. They are perfect for food on the run.

In order to achieve 12 hours of overnight sleep, I recommend 25-50g of a protein source at lunch.

When it comes to packet food and pouches I always recommend you:

1. Read the label.
There's often a lot of sugar (even if they are natural sugars, they are still sugar). What looks like vegetables could be 50% apple. Remember, our babies need to learn to eat a variety of flavors, and introducing one flavor/food at a time is important. We are also yet to find a pouch that has enough protein for this lunchtime feed. If you find one, tell us!

2. Never let a baby eat straight from the pouch.
Spoon feeding utilizes mouth muscles necessary for healthy growth and development. Additionally, toddlers can learn how to use a spoon to build fine motor skills. I always recommend using a spoon when feeding these purees. I'm not alarmist here - it's ok for toddlers to 'suck' on these pouches occasionally (we've all forgotten a spoon on the run!). However, make sure before they do this, they have started spoon-feeding themselves, eating finger foods, and drinking from a cup with minimal spilling before giving them to 'suck' on a pouch.

3. Ensure texture is introduced as your baby grows.
When food texture does not progress with the development of your baby, they are not challenged to learn how to chew. Studies have found that babies who were introduced to lumpy solids after the age of nine months ate less of the food groups at seven years old than those introduced between six and nine months old. The good news is there are now lots of baby packet foods and pouches with texture!

4. Don't depend on pouches for their only source of fruit and veg.
Packets and pouches shouldn't be the sole source of your baby's fruits and veggies. We want kids to accept fruits and vegetables in a variety of formats and textures! This is why the process of offering puree (to eat easily via the spoon), mash (to build texture and play with), and some soft finger food of the same ingredient when we introduce foods is so important.

Again, as we approach the starting of solids, my philosophy is to make food fun for both parents and babies - embrace the mess.

When you're out and about, you may not want your baby covered head to toe in what they are eating - and that's absolutely fine. Use packets and pouches when you need to, but make sure your baby is getting a variety of flavors and age-appropriate textures as they develop.

Even when you're using packets, you can still give them handheld food. There are some great dissolvable vegetable sticks that can be terrific when you're still having fun but want to minimize the mess when you're out and about!

My goal by 12 months is that children have a range of foods from each core food group to meet nutritional requirements as their milk intake declines.

It is not necessary for children to drink cow’s milk at 12 months of age. They are able to meet their calcium requirements in other ways.

Calcium requirements at 12 months of age are 500mg/day, and this could be achieved through 2 good servings of yoghurt and cheese, or alternate dairy-free options too if this is required.

Lesson Name: Constipation and Bowel Movements During Sleep Time
Lesson Content:
By 6 months of age, most children will have stopped opening their bowels overnight, however, if your baby is still having a bowel motion overnight, then try adjusting when you offer your baby fruit as sometimes this can help.

For example, if your baby has fruit after dinner, then try giving it at breakfast time instead.

If a child has 1-3 bowel movements per day at this age group, then this is considered to be normal, assuming the actual bowel movement is also a normal soft stool.

If your baby is constipated, then offering high-fibre foods and foods such as prunes, diluted prune juice, or pears can be helpful. If it continues, please speak with your doctor.

A note before you start reading. As we learned in the starting solids video & content - starting solids should be a fun process that both parents and babies enjoy.

The aim of the following two chapters:

  1. Introducing allergens
  2. Identifying allergic reactions

Is to:

  • Empower you as parents
  • Utilize the latest research and findings to guide you on the best approach to minimize the risk of an allergic reaction
  • Understand if you’re in a potentially higher risk category
  • Know how to identify an allergic reaction
  • Know what to do next if your baby does show signs of a reaction

These chapters are not meant to make you fearful of starting solids andI definitely don’t want to over-medicalize the introduction of solids.Remember there’s a 90% chance there will be absolutely no problem whatsoever.

With that said…

Allergies are on the rise:
Food allergies are on the rise in developed countries, with significant public health impact. Serious allergy (anaphylaxis) can greatly hinder the quality of life for both children and parents.

What are the most common allergens?
The 4 most common dietary allergies are to:

  • Cow’s milk
  • Egg
  • Peanut
  • Tree nuts including cashew, walnut, and pistachio

The next 5 in the cohort are still common compared to other food groups but far less so than the top 4, these are:

  • Fish
  • Shellfish
  • Wheat
  • Soy
  • Sesame

Most children will outgrow allergies to egg, milk, soy, and wheat - but it’s less likely they’ll grow out of allergies to nuts and seafood - though these may decrease in severity over time.

Common Allergens Image:


When should I introduce allergens?

  • Advice from ASCIA (the allergy governing body) recommends introducing complementary foods (including allergens) in the window of 4-6 months.
  • Introducing allergens in the 4-6 month window is associated with the lowest incidence of allergy for children.
  • Between 4-6 months, single-ingredient infant foods may be introduced, typically including fruits (apples, pears, and bananas), vegetables (green vegetables, sweet potatoes, squash, and carrots), and cereal grains (rice or oat cereal) one at a time.
  • Food can be introduced this way every 3 to 5 days as appropriate for the infant’s developmental readiness.
  • This slow process of introducing new foods and allergens one at a time gives parents or caregivers a chance to identify and eliminate any food that causes an allergic reaction.
  • Egg, dairy, peanut, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, and wheat can be gradually introduced during the same four to six-month window after less allergenic foods have been tolerated.
  • While the 4-6 month window is preferable, don’t stress if you don’t get them all in by 6 months to the day - all allergens should be introduced before your baby turns 12 months.

Never rub food on your baby's skin:
Never rub food on your baby’s skin, especially in babies with eczema, as this may increase the chance of your baby developing a food allergy. Always wash your hands after eating if your baby has eczema. Effective eczema management is one of the key ways we can reduce food allergies, so if your baby is suffering, seek help and treatment immediately.

Don't delay allergen introduction:
Delaying the introduction of these foods may increase your baby’s risk of developing allergies.

Honey should be avoided until 12 months of age:
Not for reasons of allergy, but due to the possibility of contamination with botulinum toxin - botox, which can be found in honey.

How to introduce allergens:

  1. If you’ve chosen peanuts to focus on, for example - get some smooth peanut butter and have your child lick it off your finger or a small spoon. For allergen exposure, they don’t need to swallow and ingest the food - they only need to have it in and around their mouth. Even if they spit it out - consider this enough of an exposure.
    TIP: Make sure you’re not exposing them right before bed - because you want to have an eye on them to note any potential allergic reactions.
  2. Repeat this exposure for a further 2 days.
  3. Once 3 exposures have been successful, you can then intermittently incorporate that food into your baby’s diet and be reassured.
  4. Then move on to the next allergen on your list.
  5. ​Once you have tested an allergen, keep it in their diet:
    Once you have fed your baby the common allergy-causing foods, it is important to continue to include these foods in your baby’s meals at least twice a week. Trying a food and then not giving it regularly may result in a food allergy developing.​

A note to all families:
If you have a high-risk baby, it might be beneficial to work through allergy introduction more systematically.

What babies are considered at high risk of allergic reaction?

  • A family history of food allergies
  • Atopic eczema
  • Already allergic to one or more foods
  • Parents born in Asia

For high-risk babies, the following process is recommended for introducing allergens:

  • Day 1: Swab on lip, wait 10 mins, followed by 1/8 teaspoon
  • Day 2: 1/4 teaspoon
  • Day 3: 1/2 teaspoon
  • Day 4: 3/4 teaspoon
  • Day 5: Full teaspoon



Should breastfeeding mothers restrict allergens?
There is no evidence that restricting or increasing the intake of certain foods in a breastfeeding mother’s diet will have any impact on the child.

The next section will focus on identifying and how to act if you think your baby has had an allergic reaction to a certain food.

Allergic reactions usually occur quickly - within minutes (although they can take up to 2 hours). Other reactions to foods may be delayed. Allergists can often be bombarded with long lists of foods and possible reactions from parents which are little cause for concern because parents weren’t educated on what they should be looking for - this section aims to minimize this and empower you as parents.

What does an allergic reaction look like?

Signs of a mild to moderate allergic reaction in babies to a food include:

  • Swelling of the lips, face & eyes
  • Hives or welts
  • Vomiting

Note: Minor redness around the mouth is most often due to irritation and is not usually due to an allergic reaction to the food. It is best to seek advice from your doctor as children can develop vomiting and skin rashes for other reasons that are not allergy-related. It is important that babies are not avoiding a food unnecessarily as that may increase their risk of developing an allergy to that food.

Signs of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) in babies

A baby having a severe allergic reaction to a food may experience any one of the following:

  • Difficult or noisy breathing
  • Swelling of the tongue
  • Swelling in throat (e.g. drooling, difficulty swallowing)
  • Change in voice or cry and/or difficulty vocalizing
  • Wheeze or persistent cough
  • Pale and floppy or collapse

If you are not sure whether your baby is having a severe allergic reaction or not, it is better to seek urgent medical attention as anaphylaxis can be life-threatening.

What should I do if I think my baby is having an allergic reaction?

If you notice any swelling of the lips, eyes or face, hives or welts, vomiting, or any change in your baby’s well-being (becoming very unsettled) soon after giving a new food, your baby could be having an allergic reaction - stop feeding your baby that food and seek medical advice.

If your baby is showing signs of a mild to moderate allergic reaction:

  • Stay with your baby and watch to see if there are any signs of anaphylaxis
  • Discuss the use of non-drowsy antihistamines for children under one year of age with your doctor. Sedating antihistamines should not be given.

If there are signs of a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis)

  • Lay your baby flat in your arms.
  • DO NOT hold them upright.
  • DO NOT allow your baby to stand or walk.
  • If breathing is difficult, allow them to sit.
  • If they are unconscious or vomiting, place them on their side.

Immediately phone ambulance — triple zero — 000 (Australia, including mobiles).

If it is your first exposure to a certain food and you are having a severe allergic reaction it is most likely you will NOT have an adrenaline injector.

In good news, it’s very uncommon for a baby to have a severe reaction to an allergen on the first exposure — which is why we test small amounts over a period of days.

If you have an adrenaline (epinephrine) injector (e.g. EpiPen® Jr or Anapen® Junior 150) - give immediately.

  • Phone ambulance — triple zero — 000 (Australia, including mobiles).
  • Note the time the adrenaline injector was given.
  • Give the used adrenaline autoinjector to ambulance staff when they arrive.

Sometimes a second dose of adrenaline is needed. If you have given the adrenaline injector and your baby still has signs of anaphylaxis or your baby appears to improve and then signs of anaphylaxis begin to show again, give a second dose of adrenaline if available.

What will happen if my baby does have a reaction to a certain food or foods?

After an episode, you will be referred by a doctor to an allergist. You can see Allergists in a public or private setting. More often than not, your allergist will do a prick test (sometimes called a puncture or scratch test) to measure your baby's allergic response to the allergen and prescribe you an adrenaline (epinephrine) injector (e.g. EpiPen® Jr or Anapen® Junior 150) if required.

For foods or allergens that your baby hasn’t tried yet, the process is still at-home testing as above.

Tracking Allergy Reactions:

Once you have dealt with the immediate symptoms and sought medical attention, it’s important to keep track of any reactions - this will be really important when talking to healthcare professionals about what has happened.


Download a printable Allergy Tracker HERE.

Be empowered, not alarmed

While allergies are on the rise, and we need to collectively do everything in our power to minimize the risk for our children, I don’t ever want this content to be alarmist. Remember, even if you’re in a high-risk category for allergies, there’s still a very low chance your baby will be allergic to anything.

Be empowered with all the knowledge around allergens BUT always approach starting solids with a sense of calm and fun so we can teach our babies to love food from the very beginning.

At this age, your baby still needs breastmilk or formula as a main part of their diet. Solids should be well established by now; however, many babies are still working on developing confidence with different textures and flavours.

As your baby develops an appetite for more solid food, they'll often naturally drop a milk feed or two during the day or take less at a milk feed (either breast or bottle). This isn't a problem as long as your baby is:

  • Established on solids
  • Eating well during the day
  • Still having some breastfeeds or formula feeds

FIRST FEED TO DROP:

The first feed to drop is the afternoon milk feed. This is the one given after a lunchtime nap. If you're dropping this milk feed, it's important to replace it with some afternoon tea or a snack and always offer cool, boiled water to keep your baby hydrated.

SECOND FEED TO DROP:

The next feed that is usually dropped is the mid-morning feed, usually offered around 10-11 am. As above, if this is dropped, then you should offer some morning tea and cool, boiled water.

A lot of babies will continue to have a milk feed:

  • When they wake up in the morning or after breakfast
  • Before their lunchtime nap
  • Before bedtime in the evening

⁠⁠It’s OK to cry over spilt milk. Pumping is hard work and accidents happen. Pumps leak, bags break, bottles tip (particularly when they are top heavy with a flange on top).


Make sure anyone in your home handling breast milk is aware of just how much effort that liquid gold takes to make, so they handle it with care.


PRO TIP: Remember to congratulate whomever pumped this milk - they are working overtime to nurture a baby.  Their body is doing an incredible job!



Download your printable copy of Breastmilk Storage Guidelines HERE.​

Q: Why does offering breakfast solids before milk help with early morning waking?

ANS: Babies over time can learn to wake for milk as this is their primary source of nutrition until around 6 months of age. With early morning waking, babies have a strong desire for a milk feed and can wake in anticipation.

By offering breakfast solids first (i.e., around 6:30/7 AM), it takes this anticipation away and therefore encourages a later wake-up. Babies still receive both solids and milk, so nothing changes nutritionally, just the order in which they're offered.

Most babies are on the move during this age bracket. This may involve crawling, shuffling, walking assisted, or even walking independently. Babies can exercise enormous amounts, just by dancing all four limbs or by pulling to stand and cruising along furniture.

All physical activity should be encouraged, as well as playing with toys, rolling balls to-and-fro, and dancing along to music. The more physically active your child is during their playtime, the deeper their sleep is likely to become. Swimming is an excellent example of physically tiring.

Sleep can often be disrupted due to babies wanting to practice their new skills. Learning to crawl or walk marks a huge developmental progression, however, the good news is that it usually only lasts a couple of weeks. The best thing to do, as always, is to stay consistent with your approach. If your baby wakes during a nap or overnight and they are happy practicing their new skill such as crawling in the cot, there is no need to intervene until they begin to get upset or frustrated.

I’ve seen thousands of babies over the years, brought to me due to concerns about dropping weight centiles. It’s a very necessary thing to be reviewed by a doctor, because dropping weight centiles - and even more concerning, dropping weight - can be a sign of poor growth and possible underlying problems.

It’s very distressing for parents, but it’s important to know that it can also be a very normal phenomenon. Many babies might be putting on weight adequately, but dropping centiles from a birth centile - for example, 40th - to a 6-week centile of 25th. Very often, this is what I refer to as a weight correction (see section on weight correction in 2.0 Little Baby).

When in utero, the baby’s weight is determined by the function of the placenta, adequate intake through the umbilical cord and the mother’s blood sugar levels. Babies can sometimes be born larger - or smaller - than expected. But once the baby is born, that sugar supply drops and they’re more able to regulate their calorie intake, they are bound to drop their weight centile accordingly. Similarly, babies born smaller due to a poorly functioning placenta or umbilical cord will often display excellent ‘catch-up’ growth and increase centiles accordingly.

The point is that there are many factors at play that determine the birth-weight of a baby and therefore the initial centile. But that may not be the ‘genetically predetermined’ (or likely) centile that baby was always going to be on. As they achieve a ‘correction’ in their weight centiles, we often see them gaining weight - but dropping centiles. Once reviewed by a doctor, you can trust that this is ok and not a cause for concern in most babies.

Once the weight correction is complete, babies tend to oscillate around a certain centile but generally continue to grow quite consistently. If we watch their centiles too closely however, usually by measuring weight too frequently, babies often appear to be reaching a plateau or dropping centiles again.

Serial (frequent, regular) weight measurements can often induce much anxiety. Once the baby has realised their ‘genetic centile’ then they often shift between 10 centile points above/below this over time. This is because babies go through periods of ‘rapid growth’ (less interest in food, smaller volumes consumed, more sleep, marked increase in length, weight plateau) and periods of ‘energy storage’ (high food intake, increase weight, less sleep). Babies grow like an accordion - first they grow ‘out’ and then they grow ‘up’ - once we understand this, we do not stress about a week of poor weight gain, because we trust that next week’s will likely be far better.

Also take into consideration your baby’s energy intake and output. A baby who has just learned to crawl, for example, might be moving more than ever, expending a huge amount of energy and this might explain a brief drop on the centile chart.

If you have noticed a significant centile drop or multiple centile reductions over many weeks, have your child reviewed by a doctor.

At around 8-11 months old, babies will learn to stand. This is a fantastic and exciting skill for them to learn, and they'll usually want to practise it at sleep time too. When babies learn to stand, it can be a very tricky time when it comes to sleep, and there is often a disruption due to this developmental progression. This is because they usually learn how to stand before learning how to get themselves back down.

However, you can be rest assured that babies eventually learn how to get back down from standing and be able to self-settle if they have previously been able to do this.

TIPS FOR BABIES STANDING IN THE COT

USING YOUR SETTLING TECHNIQUE DURING THIS TIME
If your baby is standing in the cot and physically unable to get down independently yet, then they're going to need your help. If using an in-room settling technique, then simply lie or sit your baby back down and remain sitting with them as you usually would. If they immediately get straight back up, continue sitting them down, but you might want to wait 30-60 seconds until putting them down again so it doesn't become a game.

If you're using an out-of-room technique such as spaced soothing, then I recommend going into them and sitting or lying them back down within a couple of minutes of them standing. Once you have put them back down, then leave the room. You may have to go in quite a few times at the beginning, but once they learn to get themselves down, this should get easier.

Don’t lengthen the check-in times of spaced soothing when this is happening, as they physically can’t lie themselves back down yet, so it’s pointless making them wait 5 minutes or longer for you to go back in. However, you might want to give them 1-2 minutes to see if they can get down themselves, as they’ll often surprise us with what they’re capable of.

  • Lots of practise during the day in their awake times.
  • Kneel behind them and help teach them how to lower themselves down by gently guiding their hips down onto your knee.
  • Gradually give them less and less support so they are able to get used to the motion of lowering themselves down.
  • Try to encourage them to lower themselves while holding onto furniture for support, either onto their knees or onto their bottoms.
  • During their awake time, practise for a short time in their cot, guiding them to hold the bars for support to help them get down from standing.

Tired signs vary from baby to baby, and it’s very normal to still be getting to know and recognise your baby’s tired signs at this age. You will generally start to see them towards the end of the suggested awake time. As your baby gets older, these tired signs may become less noticeable and less reliable. For example, as adults, we often yawn when we get out of bed in the morning, but this does not necessarily mean we are ready to go back to bed for more sleep. If your baby’s tired signs are harder to read now, then focus more on their awake time and suggested routine for their age. Your baby, however, may still exhibit the tired signs below.


I'm Getting Tired
I'm Ready for Bed
I'm Overtired
Distant looks/stares
Yawning
Hysterical Crying
Appearing bored
Eye rubbing
Arching back
More vocal/chatting
Pulling hair/ears
Stiff body
Red eyebrows/eyelids
Wanting to suck and appearing
hungry
Very difficult to settle
Starts posseting/spilling milk more
despite not being fed for some time
Making fists with hand


Jerky movements
Grizzling
​

Although babies seem to ‘grow out of teething,’ it should not be forgotten that teething continues throughout infancy. 1-year-olds will often erupt their first molars and can have an unsettled period. This can recur intermittently through to over 3 years of age.

Teething isn’t considered an illness, so it is completely fine to continue sleep training if you see some teeth coming through, as long as your baby is comfortable. However, don't underestimate the pain teething may cause and look to treat it as soon as possible.

There are plenty of remedies to try to help your baby through this sometimes painful process including:

  • teething gels
  • pain relief medication
  • teething rings
  • one of my favourites is a clean washcloth soaked in breastmilk & frozen - use an elastic band to create & secure a "ball" so they have something to suck on and something to hang onto

Teething should be considered a 24-hour process, so if your baby is miserable and showing signs of teething pain during the day, offer some pain relief before bed at night and provide extra comfort.

Excessive drooling: Increased saliva production is a common teething sign, which can sometimes lead to a rash on the chin.

Irritability: Teething can make your baby irritable, fussy, and prone to mood swings.

Chewing and biting: Babies may chew on objects or try to bite things to relieve the pressure on their gums.

Gum swelling and sensitivity: You may notice redness, swelling, or tenderness in your baby’s gums.

Sleep disturbances: Unfortunately, other teething symptoms include an extra fussy baby that can have disruptions to their regular bedtime routine. Baby wakes because teething discomfort often peaks at night, leading to disrupted sleep patterns for babies and parents – the great news is each tooth is only a 24-hour cycle, so it’s relatively short-lived (I appreciate it doesn’t feel like this when you’re in the thick of it).

Loose bowels and associated nappy rash: New teeth coming through can cause hypersalivation (excessive drooling) and therefore diarrhoea and loose bowels. Teething itself doesn't cause nappy rash, but the sensitive skin around their bottoms is more likely to be affected by diarrhoea and loose bowels.

Note: Teething will NOT increase a baby's temperature above 38 degrees. Do not attribute a temperature >38 degrees to teething, there is likely a medical cause that should be evaluated.

Lesson Name: Tips to Help Your Teething Baby
Lesson Content:
TIP 1: Chilled teething rings or teething toysGive your baby a clean, chilled teething ring, some teething toys, or a chilled damp washcloth to gnaw on. The cold sensation can reduce inflammation, help numb their gums, and provide relief. Ensure the toy or teething ring is age-appropriate and free from small parts to prevent it from becoming a choking hazard for your child.

Pro tip: If you’re using a washcloth option, soak it in breastmilk or formula, make a ball, and tie a rubber band around the middle so they have something to hold onto.

TIP 2: Gentle gum massage
Wash your hands thoroughly and use a clean finger to massage your baby’s gums gently. This can help alleviate some of the discomfort and provide soothing relief where their teeth are coming through their gums.

TIP 3: Pain relief options
Consult your baby’s paediatrician or doctor about pain relief medications that are safe for your baby’s age. Always follow your doctor’s recommendations regarding dosage and usage.

TIP 4: Dietary adjustments
If your baby has started solid foods, offer cold and soft foods like yogurt, pureed fruit, or chilled cucumber. The coolness can provide relief to sore gums.

TIP 5: Baby’s bedtime routine
Establish a calming bedtime routine to help with nighttime fussiness that includes activities such as a warm bath, soft lullabies, and cuddling. A consistent routine signals to your baby that it’s time to sleep.

TIP 6: Distraction
Engage your baby in gentle play or story time before bedtime to divert their attention from teething discomfort. Distraction can help them relax and fall asleep more easily.

TIP 7: Comfort items
If your baby has a favourite stuffed animal or blanket, make sure it’s within reach. These comfort items can provide a sense of security. Please ensure this is age-appropriate from a SIDS/safety perspective.

TIP 8: Monitor nighttime nappy changes
If your baby is in discomfort due to teething, try to minimise nighttime nappy changes to avoid waking them unnecessarily. Use high-absorbency nappies to reduce the chances of leaks.

TIP 9: Consult your paediatrician or doctor
If your baby’s teething discomfort is severe and persists for an extended period, or if you have concerns about their sleep, don’t hesitate to consult your paediatrician or healthcare provider who can also help your baby. They can provide guidance and tips and rule out any other potential issues.

While many of our parents used over the counter teething gels, and if you have older children you may have used it on them, recent guidelines have changed significantly when it comes to teething gels: 

  • Recent literature suggests that teething gels (especially those containing lidocaine) are not recommended due to the possible dosing / toxicity effects.
  • The evidence and literature is also not clear as to the efficacy of the gel in actually managing teething pain  
  • It is also not clear how much of the gel is being swallowed (as this is hard to control) by a baby and so there is concern about the potential adverse effects and toxicity. 
  • The Australian and New Zealand Society of Paediatric Dentistry also do not recommend teething gels as a solution to teething pain and a recent literature review (2020) in the Journal of Paediatrics and Child Health also recommend against the use of the teething gels containing lidocaine
  • My colleagues in the US (American Academy of Paediatrics) also do not recommend teething gels for babies either 
  • The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) in Australia hasn’t changed guidelines in Australia but the FDA (America’s equivalent to the TGA) do not recommend lidocaine gels for teething relief

Getting out of the house is so important for your own mental health, even if it’s just for a little walk around the block once a day. Getting out of the house between naps is great, but in this day and age, it’s unrealistic to expect new parents to be home for all naps.

At this age, babies can still often fall asleep easily in the pram, carrier, or car seat, so I encourage you to get out and about when you can. Aim for at least 1-2 naps at home in their cot though, as from about 6 months old, movement sleep becomes much less restorative. The shorter morning nap and/or 3rd catnap are great to offer out and about.

A breathable, blackout cover and portable white noise machine can be helpful if using the pram or car seat, as we are recreating their sleep environment like at home as much as possible.

There are many interactive classes available for babies to help with stimulation and development, and this is a great age to start these:

  • Baby sensory play
  • Baby gymnastics
  • Music classes
  • Storytime at local libraries

There are also many parent-and-baby classes that focus on parents’ well-being.

With the best of intentions, parents often like to interact with their babies as they grow and develop, especially as they become more responsive, comical and cute! Just remember not to over-stimulate your child and respond quickly to tired cues and the age appropriate sleep routines.

A bit of preparation can go a long way when organising your travel. 

Here are my top tips for flying with kids:

It’s easier (& cheaper) when they are younger:

Younger babies often sleep really well on aeroplanes because of the vibrations and white noise effect of the engines. As they get older and more mobile it does get harder to get a baby to sleep soundly on an aeroplane, and having them sleep on you might be the only thing that works. Again, this is ok and won’t cause any long term habits.

Airline bassinets are for babies under the age of two (but in my experience once they are over the age of one they can have a lot of trouble fitting in these and sleeping comfortably) There are some great universal covers you can buy that fit over both prams and plane bassinets that can ben incredibly handy at recreating their sleep environment (particularly when the cabin lights are on).

Should I fly during the day or night?

Depending on the length of the flight and age of your baby or child, there are pros and cons whether you decide to fly during the day or overnight. Sometimes there may not be a choice.

Flying during the day will create less stress about your baby or child sleeping and may be easier in terms of stress on the parent.

However, flying overnight can mean your child will be less restless and won’t need to be occupied if they sleep well.

Adjusting to new timezones:

Regarding the adjustment to new time-zones when travelling long distances, children who have sleeps during the day will often adjust far quicker than adults, due to the cyclical nature of their melatonin surges.

If possible, allow 1-2 days of relaxing after arrival, in order to adjust – you will probably benefit more than the kids!

The day after arrival, try to wake your baby around their usual time, even if they have had a broken night’s sleep because of jetlag. This is the best thing you can do to help get your baby acclimatised to the new time zone.

Medications & flying:

If electing to use medication as a sleep aid for children, it should NEVER be tried for the first time on a flight. Speak to your doctor or pharmacist and trial the medication weeks earlier to ensure there’s no allergic reaction or unexpected response; you don’t want to find this out mid-flight!

When you arrive try & stick to your usual routine:

On arrival at your destination, the most important thing is to try and stick to your baby’s regular routine, without any stress if it’s difficult to adhere to, assisted naps are completely acceptable!

On any holiday, there will be days where routine is thrown off and this is ok. If you are out and about then offer your baby their naps at their usual times. If they haven’t slept well during the day, then try your best to bring bedtime earlier to compensate.

Naps on the go will also be inevitable, such as pram or carrier naps.

Recreate their sleep environment as much as possible

When setting up a sleep environment that is unfamiliar to your baby/toddler, try to recreate their usual sleep environment as much as possible.

Take their cot sheet and sleeping bags from home so it smells familiar, blackout the windows the best you can, take a portable white noise machine or download an app on your phone and take any comforters/toys your baby is used to sleeping with.

If your baby is used to sleeping in their own room at home, then try your best to continue this while on holiday. Similarly, if your baby is used to sleeping next to you or in your bedroom at home, then continue this where possible.

Often small spaces like hotel rooms or tiny apartments are necessary when travelling, in this case – products such as a blackout cot tent/canopy can be so helpful, as you don’t have to blackout the entire room at nap times.

Returning home:

When you return home, try to get your baby back into their usual routine within 24-48 hours.

Depending on the time difference of where you have travelled to, your baby might take longer to return to their usual routine, but just do your best and use any settling techniques available to you.

Long car trips with babies and young children

Long car trips with babies and young children can be very daunting for parents, and it’s understandable that some people want to avoid them altogether. However, long car trips don’t have to be painful – as long as you plan properly.

Here are some of my favorite tips for traveling long distances with babies and children:

Make a list & ensure the trip is a team effort:

  • Don’t leave one person responsible for everything. Have a packing list that both parents tick off together.
  • If this is your first big trip with a baby or kids, remember it’s not as simple as packing when you were just a couple. Allow yourself plenty of time to pack the car or do the majority the day/night before. Whatever time you need to leave requires a half-hour window to get on the road – a dirty diaper or toilet demand just as you’re locking the front door is comically inevitable!
  • Share the driving as much as possible.
  • Be kind to each other and laugh – it’s much better than arguing.

Take into account your baby’s routine when planning the trip:

  • If confident driving in the evening, consider leaving after you’ve done their entire dinner and bath routine. They will have enough sleep debt built up to make it easier for them to fall asleep. But make sure you switch drivers regularly and get enough rest yourselves, so you’re not driving drowsy.
  • A different option is heading to bed early the night before and leaving incredibly early in the morning, like 4-5 am. Transferring them into the car in their pajamas can work – this way you can get a few hours under your belt before they really wake up in time for breakfast.
  • Another good time to leave is at nap time. Include lots of playtime and tire them out before jumping in the car so they can sleep for the first leg of the trip.
  • Keep feed and meal times the same as what they’re used to – use meal times as a good chance for everyone to stop & stretch their legs. Don’t be in a hurry to arrive at your destination, as this puts undue pressure on you and you lose the opportunity to make the journey a fun part of the holiday.
  • If your baby hasn’t slept well, then try to have a quiet day when you arrive at your destination so they can catch up and get back on track.
  • Consider an early bedtime if your baby hasn’t slept well in the car.

Focus on recreating their sleep environment:

  • Sun shades for the windows are essential.
  • For younger babies, purchasing a breathable blackout cover to put over the car seat encourages a longer nap.
  • Continue to use some portable white noise, although sometimes just the sound and vibration of the car engine is enough to put babies to sleep.
  • Use any comforters or dummies they usually have, and make sure you have numerous replacements that are easily accessible.

Keeping them occupied:

  • Make regular stops to allow your baby to have some car-free time. No matter what their age, let them move their bodies and have tummy time, practice crawling, sitting, standing, or walking.
  • Introduce some new toys during the trip. Different teething toys, soft books, and sensory toys will help pass the time.
  • For toddlers and older kids, try and plan stops near playgrounds.
  • Children’s audiobooks/stories or playlists can be enjoyable for those in the back seat… listening to the Frozen soundtrack on repeat may not be enjoyable for you (!), so create time where you can listen to your own podcasts, audiobooks, or radio.

Pack healthy snacks & drinks:

  • Remember to do this for you and the kids – it’s a long day for everyone, and eating well will help you all feel better at the other end of the trip. (Breastfeeding mothers in particular need to make sure they stay hydrated and well-fed.)
  • Even if you plan to stop and buy lunch, pack plenty of healthy snacks for along the way.
  • If you’re passing food or snacks back to toddlers or kids in the back seat, always supervise closely to avoid choking hazards.
  • Give snacks in small portions rather than large lunchboxes – this avoids the whole lot falling at their feet, as has happened to all of us!
  • Never feed a rear-facing child where you can’t supervise them eating.
  • Ensure everyone has a water bottle and avoid sugary drinks, as these may give your kids energy you can’t easily run off!

Have the things you need accessible:

  • This may sound obvious, but make sure everything you need – nappies, wipes, change mats, outfit changes, toys, snacks, water bottles, etc. – is all easy to access. It’s incredibly inconvenient when the one thing you want is at the back of the car under three suitcases!
  • If you think you’ll arrive close to bedtime, make sure portacots, sleep monitors, any bedding, and pajamas/sleepsuits, etc. are easy to pull out of the car. That way, you don’t have to unpack every suitcase when you arrive. Once the kids are asleep, you can unpack the car properly.

Remember: Babies and kids drink more than milk, so if you’re anxious and cranky, they will feed off this. Try and make the car trip as enjoyable for the whole family as possible. Be well prepared, stay safe, and don’t sweat the small stuff. Broken routines will rapidly return once the journey is over and the real holiday begins.

Happy holidays!

Some babies in this age group will be needing to start daycare for a variety of different reasons. Having family support or friends help out isn't always an option for some families, and many parents will need to return to work when the baby is 6-8 months old. Starting daycare is an exciting, nerve-wracking, anxiety-inducing, and stressful time for a lot of parents. Each family has a different set of circumstances, but I personally believe that daycare, whether it be in a large center with multiple rooms or a smaller family daycare, equips the infant with socialization skills and educational opportunities that help prepare them for the future. Having said that, daycare is not a necessary thing, and should you choose to have your child home until starting preschool, they will not be at any disadvantage.

Questions to ask when looking at centers/carers

  1. What is your ratio of children to educators?
  2. How many babies do you have in the room?
  3. Are meals/snacks provided, or do I need to supply my own? What food is offered?
  4. Are nappies/wipes provided?
  5. Where do the babies sleep? (Ask to see this space)
  6. Are you able to help my baby try and stick to the same routine he/she has at home?
  7. If I want to visit during the day to breastfeed my baby, is there a dedicated space for this?
  8. What is your sick policy?
  9. How much time do the children get outside?
  10. What are your security policies? (i.e., is there a code on the front door? Safety gate to the car park? etc.)

When choosing your centre, do what you feel is right for your family and listen to your parental instinct. While doing a tour, ask questions and don’t feel shy about asking to see the space where your baby will be napping.Speak to the educators in that room about your baby’s routine and sleep-associations, to maximize the chances of maintaining your well-earned routine.

If possible, I always recommend choosing a centre or carer that has an appropriate sleep space for infants. One that is as dark as possible with white noise playing is going to help your baby sleep as much as possible while there. Of course there will be interruptions and your baby’s sleep will probably not be as good at daycare as it is at home, but it’s important to remember this is very normal.

A good centre or carer will happily try to stick to your baby’s routine as much as possible and I encourage you to write it down for them to have everyone on the same page. Having each day as consistent as possible will help your baby adjust to daycare much quicker.

On daycare days I recommend bringing their evening bedtime forward a little earlier. Your baby has probably had a very stimulating day, interacting with little friends, exploring new play spaces, and playing with a whole bunch of new toys; this can easily make them overtired and overstimulated. Plus they may not have napped so well, so bringing bedtime earlier is the best thing you can do to set them up for a good night’s sleep and help keep on top of overtiredness.

A lot of babies start daycare at around the time when separation anxiety is starting to peak, and this can mean drop-off becomes a very emotional experience for both parent and baby.

My biggest piece of advice is not to sneak away when saying your goodbyes.

Sneaking away will just create further anxiety for your baby and not help them understand what’s going on. Instead, once you have passed them to the educator, say your goodbyes and tell them you’ll be back later to pick them up. Try to be specific: "I’ll be here as soon as you finish your afternoon snack," and then be sure to keep your promise.

Yes, a lot of babies will have a meltdown and be upset with you leaving, but most are totally fine within 5 minutes, and there are certainly lots of distractions to keep them busy. Most childcare centers won't mind parents calling to check in on their babies for some reassurance, and many centers these days also have technology to keep you updated with photos and information in real time on how your baby is doing, how much they've slept, and what they've eaten.

A common concern for parents is bottle-refusal when starting daycare. Breastfed babies who have never taken to a bottle may not be able to drink any expressed milk or formula offered to them while they’re at daycare, and this can be very stressful for parents.

It’s important to remember that your baby will be offered solids, either prepared by the centre or sent from home, during the day and also water with meals. If you have a baby who refuses the bottle, then ensure you offer them a breastfeed before sending them for the day and on returning. For some babies, they may wake during the night on daycare days for an extra breastfeed; this is ok.

If you know your baby will be starting daycare in the coming months and this is a concern, then I suggest starting to offer a bottle sooner rather than later. There is a lot more information on bottle rejection in the next chapter.

Why babies refuse bottles

Bottle refusal can be extremely stressful for both parent and baby.
I often have parents come to me in desperation as they’re heading back to work in a couple of weeks and their baby is refusing to take a bottle.

The good news is that there are ways to help your baby learn to take a bottle while not impacting your breastfeeding journey or milk supply.

Bottle refusal is more common in older babies and happens for a number of reasons:

Younger babies (<4 months)

  • Bottle refusal is far less common in this age group.
  • Babies under 4 months still have their sucking reflex, which means that anything that goes into their mouth they will try to suck.
  • The problem here is that parents can have a great experience, become complacent, and weeks or months can go by before trying the bottle again.

Older babies (>4 months)

  • Bottle refusal can be common in this age group.
  • After 4 months, your baby will lose that reflex, so sucking becomes voluntary.
  • Older babies are more likely to refuse because it’s unfamiliar:
    • The milk can taste different (even expressed breast milk).
    • The flow is different.
    • The feel of the teat is different from a mother’s nipple.

Lesson Name: Introducing Bottles – A How to Guide
Lesson Content:
Once they are taking a bottle well, I recommend giving 1 bottle every 2-3 days to keep it familiar.

Who should be the one offering the bottle?
You’ve probably had LOTS of advice about who should give the bottle, and that you’ll have more success if you let the non-breastfeeding partner or another caregiver offer it.

Well, this definitely isn’t always the case!!
Because babies, particularly older babies, need time and practice to feel comfortable with the bottle, the best person to have those practice sessions with is their main caregiver, who is often the breastfeeding mother.
This is also usually the most practical as they are the ones spending the majority of their time with the baby.

The importance of remaining calm and relaxed as a parent
It’s really important that whoever is offering the bottle isn’t stressed or anxious - remember that our BABIES DRINK MORE THAN MILK.

Your baby will pick up on all your emotions.
This isn’t to underplay bottle rejection - the thought your baby may not get enough milk is a seriously daunting thought for any parent, especially if you have no other option.
BUT… I want you to approach offering a bottle with every bit of zen-like positive energy you can muster.

  • Relax your shoulders
  • Take a huge breath in
  • …and exhale
  • Wriggle your bum
  • Smile to yourself
  • Use a calm, even voice as you talk to your baby

If you find yourself tensing up, getting flustered, and speaking in a shrill or panicked voice, repeat all these steps again - being calm as you offer the bottle as a parent is one of the number one things we can do.
Even if this isn’t how you feel at all - fake it until you make it!

How to introduce a bottle to an older baby who is refusing

First remember:
If a baby feels overwhelmed or unsafe, they won’t take the bottle.

The trick is to get them comfortable with:

  1. The bottle itself
  2. The person giving it
  3. Making sure that person (usually a primary caregiver) isn’t feeling anxious or stressed, as your baby will pick up on that.

Tip 1: Start with introducing an EMPTY bottle with LOTS of practice sessions

  • Including it in some playtime is a great idea
  • Try to keep breastfeeding away from this time
  • DON’T cradle them like you would if you were breastfeeding them

Tip 3: See which position your baby prefers

  • Try not to bring the bottle straight into their face
  • Bring the bottle gently up from below their chin



Tip 4: Let the bottle tickle their lips or chin

  • Don’t jam it into their mouth/throat
  • If your baby opens their mouth, gently let the teat be guided upwards
  • Guiding it up towards their upper palate is less overwhelming and less likely to make them gag.


Tip 5: Encourage a little suck

  • And repeat steps 1-4 at least a few times a day

Tip 6: Don’t tip the bottle until they are relaxed and comfortable

  • Once they seem comfortable with the bottle, you can tip the bottle horizontal so it offers them some breastmilk or formula.

How to protect breastfeeding and prevent breast refusal

Some babies will have no problems taking a bottle once they get used to it. It can be easy for babies to enjoy having bottles - some can even become bottle obsessed.

Your baby can get lazy with a bottle:

Just as we don’t want bottle refusal, we also don’t want babies to develop breast refusal.

That’s why offering just 1 bottle every 1-3 days will keep it familiar but also reinforces breastfeeding if this is how they’re fed the majority of the time.

How to protect your breast milk supply while offering bottles

To protect your supply, you need to make sure you have a pumping session in lieu of any missed breastfeeds.

E.g. if the non-breastfeeding parent was to give a bottle at the 10/11pm feed, the breastfeeding parent could express at 8/8.30pm and then go to bed.

If you’re concerned about supply, you may also want to consider expressing after a breastfeed in the early morning, as this is when supply is at its greatest.

It’s always helpful to keep a stash of breastmilk in the fridge/freezer when offering bottles.

  • It is often easier to feed from a bottle compared to a breast
  • The milk simply trickles out of the teat without having to work hard for it.

Best teat shape to choose and which ones to avoid

While it’s tempting to buy every type of bottle and teat when trying to get your baby to take a bottle, it’s best to stick to just a couple and avoid overwhelming your baby.

The best shape of teat has two features:

  • A gradual slope


A narrow base




​

​https://drive.google.com/file/d/1eB_ItKTZM-gB5_zmU5NgonkCqzMOzVwI/view?usp=drive_link​

Which teat flow to choose for which baby

Choosing the right flow rate is incredibly important.

  • Too slow and your baby will become frustrated.
  • Too fast (both breast and bottle) and your baby can gulp, splutter, you might see milk spilling from the sides of the mouth, gagging, coughing, and pushing the teat out.

Under 4 months old:

  • It’s best to try a slow flow teat.
  • Or one marked 0-3 months or size 0-1.

Over 4 months old:

  • Try a medium teat or stage 2, or one marked 3-6 months.
  • You could also try one marked for 6 months plus.
  • If it is too slow, your baby will be frustrated and less likely to take the bottle.

Tip: Most anti-colic bottles/teats are slow flow.

Paced bottle feeding is a way to feed babies their bottles at a pace that is more similar to breastfeeding.

When your baby is breastfeeding, they will:

  • Have a few sucks, then stop.
  • Wait for a letdown.
  • Continue to suck and swallow.

With breastfeeding, the flow slows after a letdown and then picks up again with the next letdown, with most feeds having multiple letdowns.

With a bottle feed, there is less of a slow/fast flow and more of a constant flow, sometimes overwhelming a baby if they're not used to it.

To give a bottle using paced bottle feeding:

Step 1: Keep the teat horizontal, not on the diagonal or upright, as milk just drips out in these positions. This angle is more like breastfeeding, and the baby can control the flow.



Step 2: Allow some milk to fill half the teat and let your baby continue to suck.

Step 3: When your baby pauses, drop the angle of the bottle down to give the baby a break. When they show signs of wanting more or sucking begins again, angle the bottle horizontally, fill the teat about halfway with milk, and continue.


Don't forget to give your baby some breaks and burp them thoroughly during the feed too.

Lesson Name: General Tips and Tricks for Success
Lesson Content:
Tip 1: Try using a distraction

  • E.g. Face them out and use some brief screen time with the Wiggles on.

Tip 2: Make it a focus of every awake time

  • Ie. breastfeed, solids, try with the bottle, settle to sleep.

Tip 3: A hungry baby won’t always be more willing to take a bottle

  • So don’t always try before a feed.

Tip 4: Use a baby carrier facing outwards

  • Rather than sitting baby on your knee.

Tip 5: Dip the teat in expressed breastmilk or formula.


Tip 6: Try it in the bath or in a rocker or bouncer

Tip 7: If older, try a straw cup rather than a bottle

Tip 8: If on solids, mix expressed milk or formula in purees or cereals to reduce the amount needed in the bottle.

Tip 9: If still offering a dream feed, then try at this time

We need to fill our cups:  Having a toddler (or any child really!) makes looking after ourselves mentally and physically even more important than before. 

Often with a toddler, your daily life tends to involve meltdowns, tantrums, crying, arguments and power struggles. 

Our brains soak up these experiences, and we can start to feel how our children are feeling - making us even more exhausted, but importantly - making it significantly harder for us to be effective parents.


Self care is important

  • We believe self-care is anything that makes you feel good. 

  • Just because two hours at the day spa works for your sister, it doesn't mean it will also work for you if it’s simply not something you enjoy. 

  • Whenever we speak to parents about self care it’s met with a similar line of rebuttals, revolving around guilt, lack of time, feeling lazy or practical obstacles like finances and scheduling. 

  • Some parents will also have difficulties with not having any respite as they may not have carers available for their child, and others have simply forgotten what they enjoy. 

  • You can feel pressured as a new parent when you have time for yourself - like you have to make the most of it and “do self care” but sometimes end up wasting your time trying to decide how to use it!

  • By changing the way we think about self care, we can use kindness and self-compassion to enable the down-time that we need. 


Phrases you can say to yourself might include:

  • “By taking time for myself, the family will benefit”

  • “I’m a better parent when I look after myself”

  • “I”m nicer to everyone when I’m not resentful”

  • “I am worth it”

  • OR - how would you convince a friend to take some time out for self care? Say the same to yourself. 


Pick a phrase to say to yourself:

  • As parents we encourage you to pick a phrase to say to yourselves when you’re having a rough time, like

    • “this moment will pass” or 

    • “I’m doing the best I can” or, 

    • our favourite, “perfect parenting doesn’t exist”. 


Plan one thing you’ll do for yourself each week:

  • It likely won’t be a big outing or night out, 

  • It might be as simple as ordering some pre-prepared meals so you can enjoy a nice dinner once the kids are in bed, or 

  • Reading a magazine with a cup of tea

  • Prioritising a special exercise session etc. 


As a psychologist (who is also a mum) and a paediatrician (who is also a dad), we’ve found it helpful with our toddlers and pre-schoolers, to think about activities where we could feel nurtured while still engaging with them. We’re aware that this goes slightly against the premise above in terms of nurture, but we work full-time and need to be practical! 


This could look like:

  • Going to the park and while your child plays, take a few moments to be mindful and notice the sensory experience – the sights, sounds, smells, and what you can feel. Simply spending this time being mindful can have a multitude of physical and emotional benefits.

  • Teach your child mindfulness activities while you practice alongside. It might not be quite as relaxing as it would be alone, but you will still receive some benefit!

  • If you both find it enjoyable and it wouldn’t cause further stress, engage in some creativity with your child. For example, you could get the watercolours out and both have a go of copying a picture or creating your own. Even colouring with your toddler can be very relaxing.

  • Getting toddler bike-seats fitted is a great idea so that you can get out and do some exercise in the fresh air, toddlers LOVE being on the big bike with mum and dad.

Remember, we need to look after ourselves so we can look after our kids and so that we can model self-love and care for our kids.

Food, light and social interaction all play a part in resetting our body clocks, so continually getting your child up if they wake early and offering them milk or breakfast will continue to reinforce that waking. 

Pop them back to bed if they get out and explain it’s still sleep time. Remind them the sun on the clock isn’t up and of the rules and rewards chart as part of the toddler tactics. Early waking can result from overtiredness so if your child has recently dropped their day nap then ensure you’re moving bedtime forward.

If your child is consistently waking early then it's a good idea to introduce a sleep trainer clock. There is more on this in Chapter 1.1 - Sleep Environment. A sleep trainer clock provides a visual cue to tell your child it's time to get up for the day (or get up from a nap). They're great to start using if your child is over 2-2.5 years old.

Now that your baby is over 4 weeks old, we can begin using different techniques to help settle them to sleep. We are not insisting that they self-settle at this age though, as babies up to 12-16 weeks often still need parental reassurance and a lot of hands-on settling.

Remember:cry-it-out is not recommended and should always be avoided. After all, they are still in the midst of the ‘fourth trimester’ until 12 weeks old.

Additional methods of settling - and resettling - babies:

  • Sleep cues like sleepy words
  • Shush-pat technique
  • Capped comforting

1. Introducing sleepy words to your baby:

As part of any routine, even from this early age, both parents should find a phrase or some sleepy words that you can say to your baby as you put them down for sleep. It doesn’t have to be lengthy, but just a few words they will quickly begin to recognize as a sleep cue.

Something like “night night, it’s sleep time now, I love you” or “it’s sleepy time now, sweet dreams.”

Say your sleepy words right as you pop your baby in their bassinet/cot for a sleep and repeat them once or twice before leaving them to fall asleep. If you need to resettle your baby, then repeat your sleepy words during the resettling process.

2. Shush-pat settling technique:

The shush-pat technique is useful for babies up to 4 months.

  1. Make sure the baby is showing tired signs and start the nap time ritual.
  2. Swaddle baby.
  3. Shush baby and rock gently in your arms for a couple of minutes.
  4. Place baby into the bassinet/cot.
  5. Turn baby onto their side, supporting both tummy and back with each of your hands.
  6. Continue shushing. The volume of your voice (or white noise) must match the volume of your baby’s cries if upset.
  7. Gently pat baby in the middle of the back or on their bottom. Keep the patting at the pace of a normal heartbeat (about 60 beats per minute).
  8. As baby is calmed, continue the shush-pat but slow the patting down. Continue shushing or white noise. This can take up to 20 minutes, as this is how long it takes for a baby to fall into a deep sleep state. Sometimes babies will calm but keep their eyes open. Gently stroking their nose in a downwards movement (from forehead to tip of the nose) can encourage them to close their eyes.
  9. DON’T STOP TOO SOON!
  10. Once the baby is asleep, gently roll them onto their back.

3. Capped Comforting:

This is a great technique for younger babies who don’t respond well to the initial hands-on shush-pat settling technique. Every baby has a different temperament, and while some babies LOVE hands-on settling, others are less interested.

Once put to bed, and troubleshooting is complete, give them a short period of time to try and wind down themselves, but if still upset after a few minutes, then enter their room and repeat your sleep words and comfort them as needed with examples below, trying to avoid feeding.

If your baby is well-fed and showing tired signs but struggling to fall asleep, or waking shortly thereafter, begin by troubleshooting simple measures like a nappy change, temperature check, or expelling any remaining burps.

Capped comforting might look something like this:

  • Wrap baby in a muslin wrap with arms (not legs) swaddled firmly.
  • Cuddle for no more than 10 minutes until soothed, put to bed awake and without a pacifier.
  • Leave baby for 5 minutes, even if crying.
  • If awake but not screaming, try having them suck on a clean finger or pacifier.
  • If crying is escalating, pick up and soothe again.
  • Cuddle until no longer screaming, then re-settle and put to bed again.
  • If still awake, use the shush-pat technique to help them off to sleep.

At this age, often bedtime refusal just means your baby just doesn’t have quite enough sleep debt built up, so try stretching their awake time a little longer to see if that helps things. Keep in mind the suggested routine; however, remember that every baby is a bit different, so sometimes a little trial and error is needed.

Tip: ensure your baby is having a consistent wind-down routine at bedtime, as this will help teach them to anticipate bedtime and learn that it's almost time for sleep.

Around 12 months old, babies can begin to fight their naps and bedtime, but this is very rarely a sign that they are ready to drop to 1 nap. Most babies aren’t ready to drop to 1 nap until between 15-18 months. Continue with consistency, keeping their routine on track, and offering both naps, and you should see them resolve in 1-2 weeks. It’s ok to pop them down for their morning nap a little later (i.e., 15 mins) if they are really fighting it, as this will increase their sleep debt and should make falling asleep easier.

Moving your toddler to a big bed can be an exciting transition, but can be daunting for some parents and children. Toddlers are often moved out of a cot too soon for two main reasons:

  • There’s a new baby arriving or
  • Solving a sleep problem such as climbing out of the cot.

Problem: Toddlers should remain in their cot until at least 2.5-3 years, or as old as possible. Under 2.5 years old toddlers haven’t yet developed impulse control and will likely be in and out of the bed multiple times.

Solution: If a new baby is arriving then look at buying/renting a second cot as your toddler will be going through enough new changes and keeping their sleep space consistent will help the transition. If you want to transition to a big bed because your toddler can climb out of their cot then try lowering the mattress completely to the floor (i.e. take the base off the cot and have the mattress on the floor). This makes it harder for them to climb out. Also keep them in a sleeping bag if you can as this will also limit their ability to climb out. If they are able to take their own sleeping bag off then put it on backwards to restrict access to the zip/buttons. When you feel your child is ready to move to a big bed, try and have it in the same position as their cot was and get them involved in the process (i.e. letting them help choose their linen and make a big deal of them moving to a big bed).

If you must move them to a big bed under 2.5 years old then treat their entire room as a cot and make sure their room is a safe place to be. Ensure furniture is anchored to the wall and there are no tall bookshelves or wardrobes to climb. Putting a baby gate on their bedroom door can also help if they are constantly getting in and out of their room. Sometimes a baby gate only needs to be used in the short term until they learn that their bed is safe for sleeping. Children under 2.5 years haven’t yet developed impulse control, and so this makes it difficult for them to understand the concept of staying in their bed.

Split nights occur when your baby goes to sleep well in the evening but then wakes during the night and is awake for 2 or more hours before resettling back to sleep. They usually occur between the hours of 11pm and 4am. During this awake time, they can be whinging, happily babbling in their cot and practicing a new skill, or can get upset and frustrated that they aren't able to go back to sleep, especially if they've previously been able to self-soothe.

Common Causes of Split Nights

  1. Under-tiredness
  2. Hitting a big developmental milestone
  3. Poor napping in the day
  4. Too much day sleep
  5. Bedtime that's too early

To help resolve split nights, take a look at your baby's daytime routine (see our suggested routines earlier in this chapter).

  • If they are on Option B, it might be time to switch to Option A.
  • If they are having less than 4 hrs awake time between their lunchtime nap and bedtime, try to stretch them out here closer to 4 hrs.
  • If your baby is closer to 12 months old, some are able to cope with an awake time of closer to 4 hrs 15 mins before bedtime.
  • If your baby is learning a new skill (aka reaching a new developmental milestone), make sure they have LOTS of practice during the day and aren't stuck in a pram or car seat most of the day. The more they practice, the quicker they'll master the skill and sleep should improve.

As with any baby, it's normal for there to be some trial and error involved when overcoming hurdles like split nights.

This can also be a sign your child is having too much day sleep.

As above, cut their nap back or drop it altogether from 2.5 years old and use toddler tactics to encourage positive night time sleep patterns. If they wake during the night use your settling technique with minimal interaction as this will encourage their behaviour more.​

Q: Can I alter the time I wake baby up to start their day?

ANS: Babies set their biological clocks around the 6-week mark, so having a set wake-up time can be really helpful in establishing a routine and helping your baby sleep well during the day and at night. This wake-up time can be adjusted by 15-30 minutes if your baby has had a particularly rough night or if you know that you might have a day with lots of interruptions ahead. If your baby is unwell, then this is another scenario when it is okay to forget their set wake-up time and let them have more sleep.

Q: The routine says only feed every 4 hours overnight. What happens if my baby wakes up earlier than this wanting a feed?
ANS: This is something to work towards, and we realize that some babies will wake more frequently overnight. If this happens, then try having the non-breastfeeding parent resettle baby until it is closer to the 4-hour mark, but only for 30 minutes maximum at a time. For example, if your baby wakes 3 hours after a feed, then have the non-breastfeeding parent resettle them (after offering a burp, checking the nappy, and making sure they aren't too hot or cold) for 30 minutes until offering a feed. As your baby gets older, they should be able to feed 4-hourly overnight if their calorie intake is sufficient during the day.

Q: Should I wake my baby from their naps during the day?
ANS: Yes, absolutely! If your baby is having too much sleep during the day, then it can impact night sleep. Introducing a happy wake-up will also help your baby learn to distinguish when it is time to go back to sleep and when it is time to wake up. A happy wake-up is when you quietly enter the room and wake baby up, open the blinds or turn on a light, and then make a big fuss with lots of over-the-top praise about what a good sleep they had!

Your baby will learn that quiet, sleepy words such as "night night, it's sleep time" mean it's time to go back to sleep, whereas a happy wake-up means it's time to get up.

Q: Can we start our day at 6 am or 8 am if the recommended 7 am doesn't work for our family?
ANS: Absolutely! It's always okay to do what's best for your family. However, some babies do find it harder to get into a 6-6 or 8-8 routine as they get older, and this is because of natural wake windows that begin to develop around 4 months old (more on this in the Big Baby 4-8 months program). As there are times during the day when babies are primed for sleep due to temperature and hormone regulation, adjusting their routines permanently can suit some babies perfectly well, but it just may not work for others. Try your best and see how your baby responds, and remember to be consistent and persistent while you attempt the change.

Q: What do I do with the gaps in the routine?
For example, in the 6-12 week routine, it suggests letting the baby have a nap for 1.5-2 hours, which would mean they are awake at around 10:30 am, then aren't due a feed until 11 am. What can we do in this time?

ANS: During this short period of time before they feed, feel free to let your baby have some playtime on the mat or in a bouncer, some tummy time, a brief walk outside in the pram or carrier, or some nursery rhymes and a nappy change. Anything really! If your baby wakes and is hysterically hungry, then it's okay to feed a little earlier than 11 am. This can be worked towards over time, and if your baby is used to having 3-hourly feeds, then you might want to gradually increase it to 4-hourly (as per our suggested routine) rather than stretching them all at once.

Q: It's really hard to put my baby down to sleep in the cot for the last brief nap of the day. What can I do about this?
ANS: This is VERY common, and babies will often fight this nap the older they get (more about this in the Big Baby program). It's fine to offer this brief nap as an assisted one, so that means trying things like holding them, using the carrier, pram, or car seat. Our goal is for them to have a brief nap as per the routine to ensure they aren't going to bed overtired at nighttime.

Q: My baby isn’t quite 6 weeks or still isn’t 5 kg. Am I okay to start the 6-week routine?
ANS: Generally speaking, if your baby is less than 6 weeks and/or less than 5 kg, Dr. Golly doesn’t recommend starting routines. Dr. Golly really likes babies to be nice and big/robust when they start the 6-week routine with that long stretch through the night. It’s also to ensure breast milk supply has been well and truly established if that’s how your family is choosing to feed your baby.

Q: My baby isn’t quite 6 weeks or still isn’t 5-6 kg but is already sleeping through the night. Am I okay to start the 6-week routine?
ANS: See the answer above as my general response. There may be some nights when your baby will do a nice long stretch after the late night/dream feed—enjoy these! But never push a baby to stretch these feeds if they wake for that 3-4 am feed until they meet that weight requirement. Likewise, before 6 weeks and 5-6 kg, they may be more comfortable on the 3-hour rather than 4-hour stretches between feeds. Always respond to your baby until they’re that bit bigger and more robust.

Q: My baby is only having around 1 hr 15 mins - 1 hr 45 mins awake time; however, in the routine, it suggests stretching awake time between the last nap and bedtime to 2 hrs 15 mins. Is this correct?
ANS: We don't recommend stretching your baby if they can't yet make this awake time, and the times in the routines are a rough guide. To help keep the early evening on track, you could offer a 1-hour late afternoon nap until 5 pm and then bring bedtime earlier as needed. It's never a good idea to stretch your baby too much and make them overtired, especially at the end of the day. Remember to watch your baby, not just the clock. As your baby gets closer to 12 weeks old, having a longer awake time will be easier, but they still may not reach those exact times suggested in the routine.
